title: NLDS Game 3: Huge inning lifts Dodgers to comeback win and series lead vs. Nationals
text:
CLOSE

WASHINGTON – This time, the Los Angeles Dodgers weren’t surprised by a starting pitcher coming out of the bullpen in a key situation.

The Dodgers jumped on 14-game winner Patrick Corbin in a seven-run sixth inning and cruised to an 10-4 victory Sunday over the Washington Nationals.

Relying on the depth that’s been their hallmark in a stellar 106-win season, the Dodgers awoke from their offensive slumber to grab the upper hand in the National League Division Series.

Trailing 2-1, Russell Martin put L.A. ahead with a two-run double and then added a two-run homer in the ninth to cap the scoring as the Dodgers moved one win away from the next round.

Unlike when Max Scherzer emerged unexpectedly to throw a scoreless inning in a Game 2 win, Corbin couldn’t provide a lift for the Nationals’ beleaguered bullpen. Instead, the Nationals will turn to Scherzer as a starter in Game 4 in an effort to keep their season alive.

Turning point

With the Nationals clinging to a 2-1 lead and Corbin on in relief of starter Anibal Sanchez, the Dodgers finally were able to put a couple hits together in the top of the sixth.

With two outs and runners on the corners, Corbin was on the verge of getting out of the inning unscathed when he got two quick strikes on catcher Russell Martin. However Martin wouldn’t chase a slider in the dirt and he took a fastball up out of the strike zone to even the count.

When Corbin tried to get him to chase a 2-2 slider, Martin jumped on it and split the gap in left field. As the ball bounced off the wall, two runners came around to score. In the blink of an eye, a one-run deficit became a one-run Dodger lead.

Man of the moment

Turner had a single, double home run and three RBI to ignite the Dodgers’ 12-hit attack in Game 3.

After only getting five hits and going 0-for-4 with runners in scoring position in Game 2, the Dodgers – who led the National League in scoring, home runs and OPS during the regular season – had stranded five runners on base over the first five innings of Game 3.

His three-run homer helped break open a close game and help the Dodgers regain their offensive mojo.

Dodgers players celebrate after Justin Turner's three-run homer in the sixth. (Photo: Brad Mills, USA TODAY Sports)

Manager’s special

After admitting he was surprised to see Scherzer used as a reliever in the previous game, Dodgers manager Dave Roberts sensed an opening against Corbin and pounced. With two outs in the sixth inning, Roberts sent three pinch-hitters to the plate in the span of four hitters.

All three came through with huge hits.

Lefty-killer David Freese (1.172 OPS vs. lefties during the regular season) extended the inning with a ground-ball single to right to put runners on the corners. After Martin’s two-run, go-ahead double, Roberts kept the pressure on by sending up Chris Taylor to hit for pitcher Hyun-Jin Ryu.

Taylor drew a walk to set up another two-run double from Kike Hernandez to push the lead to 4-1 and the Dodgers never looked back.

Needing a mulligan

Corbin has now taken the loss in both of the Nationals’ defeats in the NLDS. He was the losing pitcher in Game 1, despite allowing just two runs (one earned) in six innings.

He was nowhere near as sharp in Game 3, making his first relief appearance in two years. He yielded up a total of six runs on four hits and two walks in just 2/3 of an inning.

However, Corbin may get one more opportunity to pitch in the series if the Nationals can force a fifth game in Los Angeles. His relatively brief appearance (35 pitches) could allow him to come back on two days’ rest to give the Nations another lefty reliever.

State of the series

The Dodgers take a 2-1 lead into Game 4 on Monday night at Nationals Park, looking to close out the NLDS on the road.

The Nationals will have their ace, Scherzer, on the mound – just three days after throwing 14 pitches in his scoreless inning of relief in Game 2. He’ll need to throw considerably more in Game 4. “I don’t even know what the number is right now,” he said Sunday. “That’s kind of out the door. It’s just how you feel and communicate with the coaches on what you think you can do.”

Left-hander Rich Hill will be on the hill for the Dodgers, making it a matchup of two of the most intense pitchers in the game.

“I love the competition part of this,” Hill said. “Looking across the way, when you talk about guys that you really enjoy watching pitch … he’s definitely up there for me the way he competes and his intensity out there on the mound.”

Due to a knee injury, Hill only pitched 6 ⅔ innings in the second half, all of them coming in three September appearances. For that reason, he’s not expected to go very deep into the game before turning things over to the Dodger bullpen.
description: The Dodgers scored seven runs in the fifth inning and went on to win 10-4 in NLDS Game 3 against the Washington Nationals.
